_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Smith Dairy Products Company ? Milk Processing produces fluid dairy products (well cows produce the products we enhance them). Our processes involve juices, cottage cheese, milk, dips, and smaller milk packages consumed by own children in school everyday.

Our products are cooled by our ammonia refrigeration system. Cold product tastes better and lasts longer.

This facility is a food processing plant that runs a continuous operation. The regulated substance under the RMP Rule is Anhydrous Ammonia which is used in the refrigeration system. The process is a closed loop system to maintain temperature in the facility production and storage areas. 

Our system operates in a ?Carnot? cycle. The ammonia is cooled, warmed, and cooled again. The ammonia absorbs heat from the product and moves it to the outside. Ammonia is not consumed in the process. Our system contains over 10,000 pounds the RMP threshold for ammonia.


Ammonia can be hazardous. The ammonia used in our system is very similar to the household ammonia used in everyday cleaners. Just highly concentrated. 

Permissible Exposure Limit  25 PPM for 8 hours
Short Term Exposure Limit  35 PPM for 15 minutes
Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health  300 PPM
Inhalation Hazard  1,000 PPM
Skin Absorption Hazard  10,000 PPM
Lower Explosive Limit  16%
Upper Explosive Limit  25%
EPA Toxic Endpoint  200 PPM
DOT Classification:  Non flammable gas
United Nations Number:  UN 1005

Worst case Scenario for a toxic substance:

The worst case release toxic endpoint was determined using EPA's "RMP COMP.

This release would be from our high pressure receiver.

Affected within this radius are several schools, a hospital, a city park, residential, retail, and industrial areas. 

Alternative release scenario for a toxic substance. This involves the leak of a vessel. This scenairio involves a much smaller release radius.

The alternative release toxic endpoint was also determined using the EPA's "RMP COMP.

Accidental Release and Emergen

cy Response Policies:

Smith Dairy has established an in house emergency response team to quickly respond to and handle releases of Anhydrous Ammonia. The established steps include initial training under the OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.120 HAZWOPER'. The facility has also established annual retraining for all personnel that are on the HAZMAT Team as well as periodic spill drills and plant wide evacuation drills to assure all employees are prepared in the event of an emergency. Smith Dairy has also established training with the Fire Department personnel and community Local Emergency Planning Committee. These established plans and procedures shall be periodically reviewed to assure that they are current and up to date.

Emergency Response Program:

Smith Dairy has trained the refrigeration operators and selected production and office personnel in Hazardous Waste Operation and Emergency Response ?29 CFR 1910.120. The trained personnel will access each release situation and determine the appropriate emergency response to initiate. This could be by simply tightening a packing nut or flange bolt or initiating a system shut down. Smith Dairy has established written operating procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system and has included in those procedures the Emergency Shutdown and isolation in the event of a release. Smith Dairy has purchased Level B Chemical Suites, Self Contained Breathing Apparatus and other appropriate equipment to support the in house HAZMAT team. This team will coordinate their efforts with the outside emergency services to assure the safety of all.

Five Year Accident History:

During the last five year period we have had several minor leaks resulting mainly in odors around a valve or component. All of which are easily handles by our expert maintenance staff. One incident involves the release of 385 pounds of ammonia. This is equal to approximately 1/6 of a pup tank. (pup tanks are the white pill shaped tanks commonly used by farmers. This leak

was the result of a faulty valve.

In the last few months we have added a PSM / RMP Specialist to our staff. Dedicated to compliance and safety issues. We continue to improve our programs when deficiencies are found. Since January of this year (2006) we have completely revamped our Process Safety and Risk Management Programs.

Smith Dairy reported two releases in the last five years, EPA spill # 0501-85-0238 and Spill # 0502-85-0789.
On January 7th 2005 we had reported an accidental release (0501-85-238) at approximately 9:30 am; we had lost approximately 50 lbs of ammonia. Which was voluntairly reported.
On February 8th 2005 we had reported an accidental release (0502-85-0789) at approximately 3:22 pm; we had lost approximately 375 lbs of ammonia. Which was reported because it was over 100 pounds.

Through regular audits, training, maintenance, testing and inspection programs Smith Dairy has established a history of safe operation and that community emergency action plans are current and training with community services is done for a safe response in the event of an accidental release.

What does the future hold? Milk, Chip dip, cottage cheese and maybe a few other surprises (anyone like eggnog?)! As well as some safety changes. Our review of our processes continues. We are currently concentrating on site security as well as mechanical integrity. Employee participation continues to be a source of emprovement. Though its hard to improve on employee participation when we have the greatest associates in the world!
